SUPERNOTES.name: About CCProbe
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: About CCProbe

CCProbe is an open-source application that is scriptable, configurable, and supports probe-based visualization, analysis, and calibration components. CCProbe also includes components for folders, text, drawings, and images, which can be integrated with the probeware to create curricular activities and a lab book portfolio in which work can be saved and shared. CCProbe has been specifically designed to run well on handheld computers such as those running PalmOS or Microsoft PocketPC. Written in Waba, an open source subset of Java specifically designed for Handheld computers CCProbe is licensed under the GPL and it runs on PalmOS, WinCE, PocketPC, Windows, MacOS, and Unix.

The Concord Consortium is a tax-exempt non-profit education research and development organization. The appearance of new, emerging technologies has the potential to ignite explosive strides in learning capacity and curriculum development. Harnessing these technological resources can result in a powerful extension of educational resources to all people, regardless of their circumstances. The Concord Consortium is committed to leading this drive forward by developing and using the best in educational technology.

Several projects at the Concord Consortium are are collaborating to create a open source suite of scriptable and configurable sensor and model-based visualization and analysis applications that will work on many types of computers from handheld systems to desktops. The current projects contributing to the development of CCProbeware are:
- Data and Models
- Electronic Guidebook (Exploratorium)
- TEEMS (Technology Enhanced Elementary and Middle School Science)
- Modeling across the Curriculum
Find out more about the Concord Consortium here:
http://concord.org
Find out more about CCProbe here:
http://concord.org/ccprobeware

SUPERNOTES.name: Introduction
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Air Cart Introduction
Discovery Question:
What happens to a vehicle when there's very little friction?
In this activity you will build and test an air cart that operates with very little friction.

SUPERNOTES.name: Thinking About the Question
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Thinking About the Question
What happens to a vehicle when there's very little friction?

Have you ever wondered why cars stay on the road when they round a corner? Why is it more difficult to round those corners when the road is wet or covered with ice? Besides the banking of the road, the tires provide a frictional surface against the surface of the road. The ideal car provides friction when you need it (turning and braking) but has little when you don't want it (speeding along in a straight line).

It's not that easy to make a vehicle move with almost no friction. But that's the goal of this investigation. We want a cart that's almost friction free so that we can study the forces on moving objects without being confused by the forces due to friction. Suppose a frictionless cart is pushed across the floor. How far do you think the cart will go? What forces will affect the motion of a frictionless cart?
Refer to Technical Hints to see how to use the CC LabBook software.

SUPERNOTES.name: Materials
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Air Cart Materials
- CC SmartWheel
- cardboard for cart body (12cm x 40cm)
- cardboard for ramp (30cm x 100cm)
- 2 - junk CD-ROMs, with snap-in plastic hubs
- aluminum axle (15cm)
- drinking straw
- rubber bumper (popper)
- small paper drinking cup (150 ml)
- small DC motor with leads
- propeller
- 2 - new 1.5V AA batteries
- battery holder with leads
- clay (for added weight)
- accelerator acrobat
- wire for support of accelerator acrobat
- books to prop up ramp
- tape
- handheld computer
- CC LabBook software
- hot-melt (or cold-melt) glue gun and glue sticks
- utility knife
- metal straight edge ruler (metric)
- scissors

SUPERNOTES.name: Safety
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Air Cart Safety
- If you are using a hot glue gun, caution should be taken until the glue cools and hardens. Burns may result.
- If you are using a utility knife to cut the cardboard, extreme care should be taken to prevent cuts. Use a sharp blade and get instruction in how to cut against a straightedge.
- If you choose to use the propeller, keep in mind that it turns rapidly when it is powered by the battery, so watch out for your fingers!

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial I
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Building an air cart
Making the cardboard foundation

1. Carefully use the utility knife to cut out a 12cm x 40cm rectangle from cardboard for the air cart body. The corrugations in the cardboard should run the long way. Your teacher may provide this cardboard piece already cut.
2. Mark the slot for the SmartWheel probe. Be sure the slot is parallel to the cart length. The slot is 2cm wide and 14cm long, starting 4cm from one end of the cart.
3. Cut out the slot with a utility knife. Please be very careful!
Installing the axles
1. Mark the axle line. It is 8cm from the other end of the cart and perpendicular to the long side. You can use the corner of a piece of paper to make a perpendicular line.
2. Glue the straw to the axle line with hot-melt glue.Let it stick out on either side.
3. Cut off each end of the straw a bit longer than the cardboard.
4. The finished straw is now ready for the axle.

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial I, Part 2
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Building an air cart, Part 2
Attaching the SmartWheel to the Cart

1. Center the SmartWheel in the slot so that it doesn't rub against the cardboard. Make it exactly parallel to the long edge of the cart. This will make the cart go straight. The aluminum arm goes against the same side of the cardboard as the straw. Mark two screw holes with a pencil or pen, one at each end.
2. Make holes where the marks are, using a pencil or pen point. Enlarge the holes from both sides, until the screws fit snugly into them. The screws are provided with the SmartWheel.

3. Put the screws first through the cardboard from the other side, and then screw them into the arm of the SmartWheel. Tighten them until the heads squeeze the cardboard a little bit. A paper clip will work as a screwdriver.
4. Now the SmartWheel is in place. It can be taken on and off. You will need to do this for the Tracker Investigation.
Attaching the CD ROM wheels to the cart
1. Snap each CD ROM wheel onto a black hub, if this isn't already done. Put the hub on a table with the tapered end pointing up, and push the CD wheel down, snapping it into place.
2. Push the aluminum axle into the black hub on one CD ROM wheel. The long tapered end of the black hub should face toward the cart.
3. Slide the axle through the straw and then slide on the other CD ROM wheel. The picture shows the cart upside down.

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial I, Part 3
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Building an air cart, Part 3
Glueing on the bumper
Attaching the motor
1. Glue the motor on the back end, in the center, with its body sticking out a little bit beyond the cardboard. Use plenty of glue.

2. Place the batteries in the battery holder. Make sure the batteries are loaded in opposite directions in the holder. Glue it down in the center next to the motor. Leave a little bit of space between the battery holder and the motor.

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial I, Part 4
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Building an air cart, Part 4
Glueing on the clay holder
Attaching the acrobat and holder
1. To make the swinging bar for the acrobat, first bend the wire into a "U" about 6cm wide and 17cm long.
2. Bend up the ends of the "U" and crimp them a little bit. Each crimped end should be about 4cm. long.

3. Slide the crimped ends into the corrugated cardboard. If the ends of the wire are crimped, they will fit snugly into the end of the corrugated cardboard and stay firm during collisions. The acrobat needs to be removed when you mount the Force probe on the cart.
4. Put bits of clay into the acrobat's hands so that it has a good grip. Hang the acrobat on the wire.
Decorating your cart

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial II
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Building a test ramp

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial III
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Performing a coasting test

SUPERNOTES.name: Technical Hints
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Air Cart Technical Hints

SUPERNOTES.name: Analysis
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Air Cart Analysis
1. Rank your cart and at least two others in order of how they did on the friction test.
What differences in the carts might account for the results?
2. When your cart is moving, it has energy of motion.
What factors do you think affect its energy? When your cart slows down and stops, where does the energy go? When your cart slows down and stops, where does the energy go?
What happened to the motion of the acrobat when the cart slowed down? What about when the cart hit something?
What are the sources of friction for these carts? Do you think air resistance plays a role? How could you find out?
How does a vehicle behave when there is very little friction? Does it take a lot of force to get it going? To keep it going?

SUPERNOTES.name: Introduction
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Tracker Introduction
Discovery Question:
What does a graph of the motion of a low-friction cart look like?
In this activity you will explore the relationship between the movement of a cart and the shapes of the resulting position and velocity graphs.

SUPERNOTES.name: Thinking About the Question
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Thinking About the Question
What does a graph of the motion of a low-friction cart look like?

Think about how you would describe the motion of your cart to someone. What is the simplest way to describe its motion? Would you need to know its position, or velocity, or both? What tools would you need to measure its motion?
The following position versus time graph of a cart was made with a SmartWheel. Discuss the motion shown with your group. Did the cart appear to change velocity at anytime?

SUPERNOTES.name: Materials
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Tracker Materials
- CC SmartWheel probe removed from air cart
- meter stick
- masking tape
- CC SmartWheel probe installed on air cart
- CC LabBook software
- handheld computer
- constructed air cart (see Investigation: Air Cart)
- 2 - new 1.5V AA batteries
- string (for pulling cart)

SUPERNOTES.name: Safety
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Tracker Safety
- No specific safety features needed for this investigation.

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial I
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Walking off distances

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial II
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Rolling cart

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial III
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Rolling to a stop

SUPERNOTES.name: Technical Hints
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Tracker Technical Hints

SUPERNOTES.name: Analysis
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Tracker Analysis
What does the steepness of the position versus time graph tell you about the velocity of the cart? How can you tell from the graph whether the cart is going forward or backward?
2. What is the shape of the distance versus time graphs of a cart as it moves at:
constant velocity?
decreasing velocity?
increasing velocity?
How did the acrobat move during Trial II and Trial III? What happened to either make it move or keep it still during each motion of the cart?
How would you calculate velocity from the position versus time graph? Do you think that if you knew the position of the cart at every moment, you could know its velocity as well?

SUPERNOTES.name: Introduction
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Propeller Introduction
Discovery Question:
What are the effects of friction on the motion of the propeller-driven cart?
In this activity you will investigate how friction and the driving force of a propeller mounted on an air cart oppose one another.

SUPERNOTES.name: Thinking About the Question
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Thinking About the Question
What are the effects of friction on the motion of the propeller-driven cart?

If you sneeze in a weightless environment, as some of the astronauts have done, your body would move backwards and upwards. In order for a motion to happen, a force is needed. So, why does an astronaut's body move when they sneeze? What are the forces that occur during the sneeze?

Picture a propeller or fan blowing air. Think about how the accelerating air from the propeller relates to your description of the forces found during a sneeze in space. What is accelerating the air? Will your almost frictionless cart move when the propeller is turned on? Will it still move when you add more friction? What are the forces that will make the cart move?

SUPERNOTES.name: Materials
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Propeller Materials
- CC SmartWheel probe installed on air cart
- handheld computer
- CC LabBook software
- constructed air cart (see Investigation: Air Cart)
- paper clip
- string or small, thin rubber band
- 2 - new 1.5V AA batteries
- scissors
- file card
- tape
- clay

SUPERNOTES.name: Safety
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Propeller Safety
- The fan that is mounted on the air cart can hurt fingers when it is powered by the battery, so watch out for your fingers!

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial I
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Adding a propeller to a cart

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial II
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Measuring the motion of a propeller-driven cart

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial III
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Adding a friction sled to a propeller-driven cart

SUPERNOTES.name: Technical Hints
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Propeller Technical Hints

SUPERNOTES.name: Analysis
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Propeller Analysis
How does a propeller create a force that pushes on a cart?
Would a propeller work in outer space, where there's no air? If not, how could you make something move in outer space?
3. Look at your position versus time graph in Trial II.
Is the velocity of the cart constant? How can you tell?
4. Look at your velocity versus time graph in Trial III. For each case, describe the graph and then write why you think it has that shape.
no friction, push cart
no friction, propeller
some friction, push cart
some friction, propeller
more friction, push cart
more friction, propeller
Do you think the graphs are evidence that friction exerts a force like the propeller, but in theopposite direction?
6. The rate of change of velocity is the slope of the velocity versus time graph.
What is happening to the cart when the slope of the velocity graph is not zero? What is done to the cart to increase or decrease its rate of change of velocity?

SUPERNOTES.name: Introduction
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Collision I Introduction
Discovery Question:
What happens when two objects collide?
In this activity you will investigate what happens during a collision of a cart with a wall.

SUPERNOTES.name: Thinking About the Question
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Thinking About the Question
What happens when two objects collide?

Collisions happen so fast that it's hard to see what was going on during the event. You just see the results of a smashed car or a home run or a sore hand. Sometimes you want big forces, as with a baseball bat or a karate chop, and sometimes you want to decrease the forces, as with a safety helmet.

In this activity you will use the Force probe to actually measure what happens during a collision. How big are the forces? How long do they last? What features of the colliding objects make the forces bigger or smaller? How would you increase or decrease the forces during a collision?

SUPERNOTES.name: Materials
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Collision I Materials
- CC SmartWheel probe
- CC Force probe
- handheld computer
- CC LabBook software
- long rubber band or several cut rubber bands and joined together (so when they are cut and joined it has a length of 1/2m)
- constructed air cart (see Investigation: Air Cart)
- books or (optional) a ring stand

SUPERNOTES.name: Safety
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Collision I Safety
- Be careful with stretched rubber bands. They can hurt if you let them go and they hit someone!
- The fan that is mounted on the air cart can hurt fingers when it is powered by the battery, so watch out for your fingers!

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial I
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Weighing the cart with the Force probe

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial II
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Colliding a cart with a wall

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial III
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Adding a bungee cord

SUPERNOTES.name: Technical Hints
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Collision I Technical Hints

SUPERNOTES.name: Analysis
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Collision I Analysis
1. Compare the bumper event and the rubber band event.
How long did each collision take? What was the maximum force? What was the shape of the graph?
What is the relationship between the behavior of the acrobat and the shape and size of the force graph?
Why do you think the forces were different for the bumper versus the bungee cord?
4. Consider riding on the cart.
Which collision would you prefer, a collision with a wall or a collision using a bungee cord? Why?
How could you decrease the maximum force when the cart hits the Force probe? Explain why your idea would work.

SUPERNOTES.name: Introduction
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Collision II Introduction
Discovery Question:
When two objects hit, is the force on one the same as the force on the other?
In this activity you will investigate what happens during a collision between two carts.

SUPERNOTES.name: Thinking About the Question
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Thinking About the Question
When two objects hit, is the force on one the same as the force on the other?
Suppose two identical balls bounce off of each other. Does each one experience the same force? Will they each bounce off with the same velocity they started with?

In your group, predict and explain what happens when two objects with different masses, like a heavy and a light ball or a heavy truck and a small car collide. Is the force on each one the same? What is the resulting motion of each object?

SUPERNOTES.name: Materials
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Collision II Materials
- CC SmartWheel probe
- CC Force probe
- handheld computer
- CC LabBook software
- 2 - long rubber bands (so they have a length of about 30cm when cut)
- constructed air carts (see Investigation: Air Cart)
- hot-melt (or cold-melt) glue gun and glue sticks
- paper clip
- pencil or pen

SUPERNOTES.name: Safety
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Collision II Safety
- Be careful with stretched rubber bands. They can hurt if you let them go and they hit someone!

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial I
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Action and reaction

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial II
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Forces on colliding carts

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial III
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Velocities of colliding carts

SUPERNOTES.name: Technical Hints
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Collision II Technical Hints

SUPERNOTES.name: Analysis
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Collision II Analysis
1. Trials I and II are examples of Newton 's famous assertion that "for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction."
Does it seem to be true in both cases? Is the result surprising?
If you were pushing on each other with Force probes instead of pulling, would they still read the same?"
If one of the Force probes were attached to a wall and you were pulling on the other one, would they read the same force?
If a light cart hit a heavy cart at rest, what would you say now about the force on each one and their speeds after the collision?
5. Newton's Second Law asserts that a force is needed to change the velocity of an object. The greater the force, the more quickly the velocity changes.
Describe an experiment to test this theory.

SUPERNOTES.name: think1 predict frictionless
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: It's not that easy to make a vehicle move with almost no friction. But that's the goal of this investigation. We want a cart that's almost friction free so that we can study the forces on moving objects without being confused by the forces due to friction. Suppose a frictionless cart is pushed across the floor.
How far do you think the cart will go?
What forces will affect the motion of a frictionless cart?

SUPERNOTES.name: trial1 explain slopes
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Experiment with different slopes and distances up the ramp.
How do slope and distance affect how far the cart will roll?
What arrangement is the best for testing the friction of the cart?

SUPERNOTES.name: trial1 predict test
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Propose a way to test the relative friction of the carts, without using the motor and fan. You can use the ramp, however. HINT: Decide on a distance, a way to start together, and a way to compare your cart with at least three other carts.
Should they all race together on separate ramps, or race one by one and compare them?
Do they get more than one run?
Do you think this is a fair test of the friction of the cart?

SUPERNOTES.name: trial2 describe race
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Race your air cart with at least three other carts by rolling them down the ramp. Observe the motion of the acrobat during the race.
What is your measure of friction?
Which one has the least friction?

SUPERNOTES.name: analysis1 describe rank
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Rank your cart and at least two others in order of how they did on the friction test.
What differences in the carts might account for the results?

SUPERNOTES.name: analysis2 explain motion
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: When your cart is moving, it has energy of motion.
What factors do you think affect its energy?
When your cart slows down and stops, where does the energy go?
When your cart slows down and stops, where does the energy go?

SUPERNOTES.name: analysis3 describe acrobat
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: What happened to the motion of the acrobat when the cart slowed down?
What about when the cart hit something?

SUPERNOTES.name: analysis4 explain friction
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: What are the sources of friction for these carts?
Do you think air resistance plays a role?
How could you find out?

SUPERNOTES.name: analysis5 explain vehicle
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: How does a vehicle behave when there is very little friction?
Does it take a lot of force to get it going?
To keep it going?

SUPERNOTES.name: think1 predict motion
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Think about how you would describe the motion of your cart to someone.
What is the simplest way to describe its motion?
Would you need to know its position, or velocity, or both?
What tools would you need to measure its motion?

SUPERNOTES.name: think2 describe position
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: The following position versus time graph of a cart was made with a SmartWheel. Discuss the motion shown with your group.
Did the cart appear to change velocity at anytime?

SUPERNOTES.name: trial1 describe movements
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Draw and describe the graph for each set of movements in Notes on your handheld computer.
walking forward at a constant velocity
walking forward, then backward, at constant velocity
walking forward slowly, then quickly, then stopping
gradually speeding up, then gradually slowing down

SUPERNOTES.name: trial1 predict graphs
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Predict the resulting graphs for each of the following motions in Notes on your handheld computer.
pulling the cart forward at a constant velocity
pulling the cart at a slow constant velocity, then a faster constant velocity, then coasting
gradually speeding up the cart, then coasting
pulling the cart, then letting it bounce off a wall

SUPERNOTES.name: trial2 describe movements
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Draw and describe a graph for each set of movements in Notes on your handheld computer.
pulling the cart forward at a constant velocity
pulling the cart at a slow constant velocity, then a faster constant velocity, then coasting
gradually speeding up the cart, then coasting
pulling the cart, then letting it bounce off a wall

SUPERNOTES.name: trial3 describe AcrobatRespond
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Discuss the following questions with your group.
What do the graphs show you about the motion of the cart?
How did the acrobat respond during the constant motion and the changing motion?

SUPERNOTES.name: trial1 describe design
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Using the ramp to initiate motion of the cart, design a method to slow down the cart and bring it to a stop in exactly 5 seconds as it rolls across a rug or another rough surface. Share your method with other members of your group.
What is your method?

SUPERNOTES.name: trial2 describe looklike
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: What will the position versus time graph look like?

SUPERNOTES.name: trial3 describe slowdown
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Look at your position versus time graph.
How do you know that your cart slowed down?
Did it slow down at the same rate for the entire 5 seconds?
If not, when and why did the rate change?

SUPERNOTES.name: analysis1 explain steepness
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: What does the steepness of the position versus time graph tell you about the velocity of the cart?
How can you tell from the graph whether the cart is going forward or backward?

SUPERNOTES.name: analysis2 describe shape
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: What is the shape of the distance versus time graphs of a cart as it moves at:
constant velocity?
decreasing velocity?
increasing velocity?

SUPERNOTES.name: analysis3 describe keepstill
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: How did the acrobat move during Trial II and Trial III?
What happened to either make it move or keep it still during each motion of the cart?

SUPERNOTES.name: analysis4 explain calculate
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: How would you calculate velocity from the position versus time graph?
Do you think that if you knew the position of the cart at every moment, you could know its velocity as well?

SUPERNOTES.name: think1 explain astronaut
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: If you sneeze in a weightless environment, as some of the astronauts have done, your body would move backwards and upwards. In order for a motion to happen, a force is needed. So, why does an astronaut's body move when they sneeze?
What are the forces that occur during the sneeze?

SUPERNOTES.name: think2 predict fan
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Picture a propeller or fan blowing air. Think about how the accelerating air from the propeller relates to your description of the forces found during a sneeze in space.
What is accelerating the air?
Will your almost frictionless cart move when the propeller is turned on?
Will it still move when you add more friction?
What are the forces that will make the cart move?

SUPERNOTES.name: trial1 explain finger
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Turn the propeller with your finger. Look at its shape.
How can you tell which way the air will blow?

SUPERNOTES.name: trial2 explain correct
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Was your prediction correct? If not, write a better explanation.

SUPERNOTES.name: trial3 describe carefully
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: While still holding onto your cart, carefully hold your other hand in front of and behind the propeller while it is on. Do you feel air moving in both locations or only in one? Is this the same as what you predicted?
What is the difference you observe and why do you think it's that way?

SUPERNOTES.name: trial1 describe straightline
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: What is the shape of the position graph? Is it a straight line?
Why do you think it has this shape?
What would it look like if your cart could keep going farther?

SUPERNOTES.name: analysis1 explain pushes
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: How does a propeller create a force that pushes on a cart?

SUPERNOTES.name: analysis2 explain outerspace
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Would a propeller work in outer space, where there's no air?
If not, how could you make something move in outer space?

SUPERNOTES.name: analysis3 describe positiontime
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Look at your position versus time graph in Trial II.
Is the velocity of the cart constant?
How can you tell?

SUPERNOTES.name: analysis4 describe velocitytime
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Look at your velocity versus time graph in Trial III. For each case, describe the graph and then write why you think it has that shape.
no friction, push cart
no friction, propeller
some friction, push cart
some friction, propeller
more friction, push cart
more friction, propeller

SUPERNOTES.name: analysis5 explain opposite
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Do you think the graphs are evidence that friction exerts a force like the propeller, but in theopposite direction?

SUPERNOTES.name: analysis6 explain ratechange
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: The rate of change of velocity is the slope of the velocity versus time graph.
What is happening to the cart when the slope of the velocity graph is not zero?
What is done to the cart to increase or decrease its rate of change of velocity?

SUPERNOTES.name: think1 predict forces
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: In this activity you will use the Force probe to actually measure what happens during a collision. How big are the forces? How long do they last? What features of the colliding objects make the forces bigger or smaller?
How would you increase or decrease the forces during a collision?

SUPERNOTES.name: trial1 explain newtons
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Weigh something heavy, like a book. Note that the units are in newtons, not kilograms.
What is the difference between newtons and kilograms?

SUPERNOTES.name: trial2 describe steady
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: What was the average value for the weight of the cart?
How steady was your reading?
How much did it vary and why?

SUPERNOTES.name: trial3 predict hangcart
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: If you hang the cart with a rubber band and weigh it, will it be the same? Try it.

SUPERNOTES.name: trial4 describe variations
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: What variations do you get?
Can you get a steady reading?

SUPERNOTES.name: trial5 describe calculate
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Calculate the mass, in kilograms, of your cart. The conversion is mass (kg) = weight (newtons) / 9.8
What are the weight and the mass?

SUPERNOTES.name: trial6 explain compare
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: How does this mass compare to the masses of the other carts.

SUPERNOTES.name: trial1 describe maximum
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Answer the following in Notes on your handheld computer:
What is the shape of the graph?
How long did the collision take?
What was the maximum force?
What did the acrobat do during the collision?

SUPERNOTES.name: trial1 describe shapeplot
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Answer the following in Notes on your handheld computer:
What is the shape of the plot?
How long did the collision take?
What was the maximum force?
What did the acrobat do during the collision?

SUPERNOTES.name: analysis1 describe bumper
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Compare the bumper event and the rubber band event.
How long did each collision take?
What was the maximum force?
What was the shape of the graph?

SUPERNOTES.name: analysis2 explain relationship
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: What is the relationship between the behavior of the acrobat and the shape and size of the force graph?

SUPERNOTES.name: analysis3 explain bungee
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Why do you think the forces were different for the bumper versus the bungee cord?

SUPERNOTES.name: analysis4 explain prefer
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Consider riding on the cart.
Which collision would you prefer, a collision with a wall or a collision using a bungee cord?
Why?

SUPERNOTES.name: analysis5 explain hits
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: How could you decrease the maximum force when the cart hits the Force probe?
Explain why your idea would work.

SUPERNOTES.name: think1 predict balls
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Suppose two identical balls bounce off of each other.
Does each one experience the same force?
Will they each bounce off with the same velocity they started with?

SUPERNOTES.name: think2 predict masses
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: In your group, predict and explain what happens when two objects with different masses, like a heavy and a light ball or a heavy truck and a small car collide.
Is the force on each one the same?
What is the resulting motion of each object?

SUPERNOTES.name: trial1 predict tug
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Each team member will pull on one of the Force probes, much like a tug-of-war.
When do you think the two force graphs will be the same?
When do you think the two force graphs will be different?

SUPERNOTES.name: trial2 explain correct
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Compare the graphs from the two force probes.
What can you conclude?
Was your prediction correct?

SUPERNOTES.name: trial1 predict twocarts
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Predict what the force graphs will look like if you roll the two carts toward each other.
What if they have about the same velocity?
What if you roll one cart toward the other which is not moving?

SUPERNOTES.name: trial2 describe look
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Look at the force graphs for both teams.
Were they the same for both carts?
How long did the collision take?
What was the maximum force?

SUPERNOTES.name: trial1 predict stationary
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Predict what the velocity graphs will look like if one cart is stationary and you roll the other cart against it.
What will be the velocity for each cart before and after the collision?
What will the velocity graph do just at the moment of collision?

SUPERNOTES.name: trial2 describe values
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Look at the velocity graphs for both teams.
Were they what you predicted?
How did the initial velocity of one cart compare with the final velocity of the other?
Draw the velocity graph for each cart, and write in the velocity values.

SUPERNOTES.name: analysis1 explain suprising
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Trials I and II are examples of Newton 's famous assertion that "for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction."
Does it seem to be true in both cases?
Is the result surprising?

SUPERNOTES.name: analysis2 explain pushing
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: If you were pushing on each other with Force probes instead of pulling, would they still read the same?"

SUPERNOTES.name: analysis3 explain wall
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: If one of the Force probes were attached to a wall and you were pulling on the other one, would they read the same force?

SUPERNOTES.name: analysis4 explain lightcart
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: If a light cart hit a heavy cart at rest, what would you say now about the force on each one and their speeds after the collision?

SUPERNOTES.name: analysis5 describe change
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Newton's Second Law asserts that a force is needed to change the velocity of an object. The greater the force, the more quickly the velocity changes.
Describe an experiment to test this theory.

SUPERNOTES.name: Introduction
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Heat Flow Introduction
Discovery Question:
What happens when two objects at different temperatures are left in contact with each other?
In this activity you will investigate how to alter heat flow.

SUPERNOTES.name: Thinking About the Question
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Thinking About the Question
What happens when two objects at different temperatures are left in contact with each other?

We are constantly dealing with things at different temperatures. Sometimes we want the heat to flow faster (cooking) and sometimes we want to prevent its flow (sleeping bags). In your group, discuss other situations when you would want to alter heat flow. What are three such situations? How does energy flow change over time?

Sometimes we prefer uniform temperatures (a non-drafty room) and sometimes we prefer contrast (hot syrup on ice cream). Can you think of other times when you want uniform or non-uniform temperatures? Which condition (uniform or non-uniform) is easier to keep for the longest period of time?

SUPERNOTES.name: Materials
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Heat Flow Materials
- CC Fast Response Temperature probe
- handheld computer
- CC LabBook software
- Styrofoam cup
- film canister (to measure water volume)
- small ball of clay (size of a large or shooter marble)
- paper towel (to dry off clay)
- water at two temperatures (warm tap water and ice water)

SUPERNOTES.name: Safety
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Heat Flow Safety
- No specific safety features needed for this activity.

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial I
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Mixing the bath water just right

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial II
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Reaching equilibrium in temperature

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial III
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Using insulation to prevent heat flow

SUPERNOTES.name: Technical Hints
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Heat Flow Technical Hints
- Setting up the Temperature probe
- Using the CC Lab Book software

SUPERNOTES.name: Analysis
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Heat Flow Analysis

While mixing water at two temperatures, did the result match your prediction? If they differed, why? Derive a formula for the final temperature when you mix equal amounts of different temperatures of water.
Which exchanged heat faster, the water mixed together or the clay in the water? Why?
Draw the resulting graph of the clay temperature as it approaches the temperature of the water. Why do you think it has that shape?
Do you think the shape of the clay makes a difference in the results? Give examples of other shapes besides a ball that you could use and how they would behave differently.
How did your method of insulation compare to methods used by others? Explain why the differences occurred.

SUPERNOTES.name: Introduction
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Potential and Kinetic Energy Introduction
Discovery Question:
When you roll a cart up and down a ramp, it changes velocity. If the total amount of energy is always the same, how does it change form?
In this activity you will relate the movement and energy of a cart as it rolls up and down a ramp.

SUPERNOTES.name: Thinking About the Question
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Thinking About the Question
When you roll a cart up and down a ramp, it changes velocity. If the total amount of energy is always the same, how does it change form?

A basketball player going for a lay up is a good example of an object in motion. Just as the player is ready to release the ball, the player exhibits both gravitational potential energy (how high the player jumps) and the kinetic energy of motion (how fast the player isgoing). How do these two energies relate?

Think about what happens when you are playing on a playground swing. How does the amount of energy change when you are near the ground compared to the amount of energy at the top of your swing? Use Notes on your handheld computer to draw the motion of a swing. Where is the (gravitational) potential energy the greatest? Where is the kinetic energy the greatest?

SUPERNOTES.name: Materials
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Potential and Kinetic Energy Materials
- CC SmartWheel probe
- handheld computer
- CC Lab Book software
- constructed air cart (see Investigation: Air Cart)
- cardboard ramp (see Investigation: Air Cart)
- books to prop up ramp
- measuring tape or meter stick
- rubber bands

SUPERNOTES.name: Safety
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Potential and Kinetic Energy Safety
- Be careful with stretched rubber bands. They can hurt if you let them go and they hit someone!

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial I
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Rolling a cart down a hill

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial II
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Changing the starting height of the cart

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial III
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Bouncing a cart down and up a hill Bouncing a cart down and up a hill Bouncing a cart down and up a hill

SUPERNOTES.name: Technical Hints
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Potential and Kinetic Energy Technical Hints
- Connecting cables from the SmartWheel to the handheld computer
- Using the CC Lab Book software
- Opening saved data in the CC Lab Book software

SUPERNOTES.name: Analysis
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Potential and Kinetic Energy Analysis

1. In Trials I and II, the cart has two forms of energy. The first, gravitational potential energy, is proportional to an object's height above the Earth. The higher an object, the more gravitational potential energy it has. When in each trial did the cart have the greatest potential energy? Why?
2. The second form is kinetic energy, also called energy of motion. It depends on an object's velocity. When in each trial did the cart have the greatest kinetic energy? Why?
3. Do you think the cart has as much kinetic energy at the bottom of the ramp as it had potential energy at the top of the ramp? Why?

4. Energy can also be stored in a stretched rubber band. It's another form of potential energy. If you "hang" a cart down a ramp with a rubber band, then let it bounce up and down, energy is going from (gravitational potential) to (kinetic) to (rubber band potential). Look at your data from Trial III. Where on the graph is each kind of energy the greatest?
5. After the cart leaves the ramp, it slows down, losing its kinetic energy. Where does the energy go?

6. We often want to store energy for later use. How many examples of this can you list? In each case, what is the form of stored energy, and what is the form of useful energy that comes from it? Hint: The useful energy might not always be kinetic energy; it might be light from a bulb, or heat in a room.

SUPERNOTES.name: Introduction
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Heating with Electricity Introduction
Discovery Question:
Can electricity be used to heat things?
In this activity you will investigate heating with electrical devices.

SUPERNOTES.name: Thinking About the Question
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Thinking About the Question
Can electricity be used to heat things?

When electricity flows through a wire, some of its energy goes into heating up the wire. Sometimes this is a problem. When electricity travels from a power station to the city, heat energy is wasted. But once the electricity arrives at your house for the purpose of heating a stove or a room, electrical heating is very efficient and flexible.

The Genecon is a little generator with the same basic design as the huge generators run by hydroelectric dams, coal-fired boilers, or nuclear power plants. In every case, some other form of energy (e.g., falling water, burning coal, decaying radioactive material) turns the "crank" of a generator and creates electrical power. In this case, you supply the power. Make a list in Notes on your handheld computer of several ways that electric power is generated and the source of energy in each case.

SUPERNOTES.name: Materials
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Heating with Electricity Materials
- CC Fast Response Temperature probe
- CC Voltage/Current
- handheld computer
- CC Lab Book software
- handheld generator (Genecon)
- heat cell with insulating cover
- mini light
- battery pack
- 2 - new 1.5V AA batteries
- clip leads

SUPERNOTES.name: Safety
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Heating with Electricity Safety
- Although the hand-held generator is sturdily constructed, excessive speed in rotating the handle can result in stripped gears.
- While lighting the mini light with your Genecon, keep in mind that the mini light will become hot to the touch. The mini light will also burn out if you crank the Genecon too fast.

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial I
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Cranking with a Genecon

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial II
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Heating with a battery

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial III
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Heating with a light bulb

SUPERNOTES.name: Technical Hints
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Heating with Electricity Technical Hints
- Setting up the Voltage/Current probe
- Using the CC Lab Book software for the Voltage/Current probe
- Setting up the Temperature probe
- Using the CC Lab Book software for the Temperature probe
- Opening saved data in the CC Lab Book software

SUPERNOTES.name: Analysis
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Heating with Electricity Analysis

1. Discuss the shape of the temperature graph when you supplied electrical energy to the heat cell with the Genecon. Does it start to heat right away? What does the slope of the line tell you? Is it the same for fast and slow cranking?
2. Compare the rate of heating by the Genecon and the batteries. Which heats faster? How can you tell? Are you surprised by the amount of cranking it takes to equal what a small battery can do?
3. Is the amount of cooling significant over the period of 60 seconds?
4. Is the shape of the graph for cooling the same as the shape for heating? How long do you think it would take for the heat cell to cool down to the starting temperature?
5. Do you think the energy in the battery could properly be called "potential" energy? What form do you think it is in?
6. Why did the light bulb heat up so much more rapidly than the heat cell?

7. Compare the tape teams' data with the foil teams' data. Did the bulb heat up faster with the clear tape or the aluminum foil? Explain how you think the light bulb becomes hot and what difference the covering makes.

SUPERNOTES.name: Introduction
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Forms of Energy: Single Transformations Introduction
Discovery Question:
Can all forms of energy be transformed from one form to another?
In this activity you will investigate the benefits of changing one form of energy into another form of energy.

SUPERNOTES.name: Thinking About the Question
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Thinking About the Question
Can all forms of energy be transformed from one form to another?

Energy comes in many forms - electrical, mechanical, chemical, light, nuclear - and it can be stored in many ways - batteries, springs, water towers, gasoline, radioactive materials. To make use of energy, we often want to change it from one form to another, then store it, then transform it again and use it later on.

How many kinds of energy can you think of that you make use of in and around your house? Where does each kind come from? How is it stored before you use it? Is it changed from one form to another when you make use of it? What do you do with the energy? On your handheld, answer these questions for each kind of energy.

SUPERNOTES.name: Materials
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Forms of Energy: Single Transformations Materials
- CC Voltage/Current probe
- CC Light probe
- CC Fast Response Temperature probe
- handheld computer
- CC Lab Book software
- handheld generator (Genecon)
- capacitor (1 Farad)
- constructed air cart (see Investigation: Air Cart) wire clip leads
- wire clip leads
- heat cell
- Fresnel plastic lens (5cm x 8 cm)
- black marker or carbon from a burnt candle wick
- sunlight or incandescent light bulb in a lamp with no shade

SUPERNOTES.name: Safety
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Forms of Energy: Single Transformations Safety
- When the Fresnel lens focuses sunlight, it produces a concentrated beam of light. Be very careful and never focus the beam on yourself or anyone else!
- Never look directly at the sun. Damage to your eyes will result.

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial I
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Storing electrical energy

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial II
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Using stored electrical energy

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial III
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Heating with sunlight

SUPERNOTES.name: Technical Hints
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Forms of Energy: Single Transformations Technical Hints
- Setting up the Voltage/Current probe
- Using the CC Lab Book software for the Voltage/Current probe
- Setting up the Temperature probe
- Using the CC Lab Book software for the Temperature probe

SUPERNOTES.name: Analysis
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Forms of Energy: Single Transformations Analysis

1. When you charged the capacitor with the Genecon, then ran the Genecon with the capacitor, do you think you obtained as much mechanical energy out of the capacitor as you put in it? How could you find out? If you didn't, where did the energy go?

2. Capacitors, with their ability to store electrical energy and release it very fast, have many uses. A familiar one is the flash on a camera. A very small amount of energy is released so fast that it makes a bright, but brief, light. This is just what a camera needs! But when you want a slow, steady supply of energy, as with the air cart motor, a capacitor is not the best source of energy. A battery is much better. Think of other situations that use batteries and capacitors for electrical energy storage.

3. The Fresnel lens concentrates light from a larger area to a smaller area, by bending the light that comes through it. This is called refraction. How much do you think the Fresnel lens magnified the amount of sunlight reaching the heat cell compared to just letting it sit out in the Sun without the lens? Compare the area of the Fresnel lens to the area of the focused light on the heat cell.
4. How many devices can you think of that use lenses to focus light?

5. How do you think sunlight is converted into heat? Do you think it matters if the heat cell is black instead of plain aluminum? Can heat be converted back into light? If so, list some examples of this type of conversion.

SUPERNOTES.name: Introduction
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Forms of Energy: Multiple Transformations Introduction
Discovery Question:
What energy transformations are used in everyday devices?
In this activity you investigate energy being transformed through several steps to obtain a useful form.

SUPERNOTES.name: Thinking About the Question
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Thinking About the Question
What energy transformations are used in everyday devices?

We use many devices that transform energy from one form to another. Sometimes a whole chain of transformations takes place. They often do it so smoothly that we don't even realize what's happening. Each step usually involves some loss of useful energy. An automobile engine, for instance, is only 30 per cent efficient. That is, only 30 percent of the available energy in gasoline is available to move the car.

Think of some examples where energy is transformed several times before it is used. In your handheld Notes, list each of the forms of energy in the chain, and what you think the efficiency is for each step. Where do you think the wasted energy goes?

SUPERNOTES.name: Materials
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Forms of Energy: Multiple Transformations Materials
- CC Voltage/Current probe
- CC Light probe
- handheld computer
- CC Lab Book software
- solar cell
- sunlight
- clip leads
- capacitor (1 Farad)
- mini light
- black film canister
- aluminum foil
- handheld generator (Genecon)
- pulley wheel and plastic bushing
- string
- 50g mass
- paper clip
- clay

SUPERNOTES.name: Safety
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Forms of Energy: Multiple Transformations Safety
- Never look directly at the sun. Damage to your eyes will result.
- Although the hand-held generator is sturdily constructed, excessive speed in rotating the handle can result in stripped gears.
- While lighting the mini light with your Genecon, keep in mind that the mini light will become hot to the touch.

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial I
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Electricity from the sun

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial II
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Cranking up the lights

SUPERNOTES.name: Trial III
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Remote lifting

SUPERNOTES.name: Technical Hints
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Forms of Energy: Multiple Transformations Technical Hints
- Setting up the Voltage/Current probe
- Using the CC Lab Book software for the Voltage/Current probe
- Setting up the Light probe
- Using the CC Lab Book software for the Light probe
- Drawing in the CC Lab Book software

SUPERNOTES.name: Analysis
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Forms of Energy: Multiple Transformations Analysis
1. You built a solar car in Trial I! What other features would it need to be a practical vehicle?
2. Open the data from Trials II. Compare all of the different light levels you measured. What was the maximum level? What was the minimum level?

3. You were asked to rate the efficiency of each energy transformation. Low efficiency means that useful energy is lost. Where does the lost energy go, in the case of the Genecon, the solar cell, and the light bulb?

4. Open the data from Trial III. Compare the energy graph with your list of what you were doing with the two Genecons and the attached mass. What does the graph tell you about energy transfer from one Genecon to the other?

5. Design an energy "Rube Goldberg" machine. This type of machine is a wacky series of devices that change energy through various forms and ends up serving a purpose. Make a drawing of your Rube Goldberg on your handheld computer. Refer to Technical Hints to see draw in the software. Please no live animals!

SUPERNOTES.name: think1 predict cooking
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: We are constantly dealing with things at different temperatures. Sometimes we want the heat to flow faster (cooking) and sometimes we want to prevent its flow (sleeping bags). In your group, discuss other situations when you would want to alter heat flow.
What are three such situations?
How does energy flow change over time?

SUPERNOTES.name: think2 predict uniform
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Sometimes we prefer uniform temperatures (a non-drafty room) and sometimes we prefer contrast (hot syrup on ice cream).
Can you think of other times when you want uniform or non-uniform temperatures?
Which condition (uniform or non-uniform) is easier to keep for the longest period of time?

SUPERNOTES.name: trial1 describe temp
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Start the software and observe the temperature versus time graph as you test your two choices of water. Stop the software. Be sure the two samples are at least 10 degrees Celsius differentfrom each other.
What are the two temperatures?

SUPERNOTES.name: trial2 describe mixing
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Before mixing the two samples of water together, predict the final temperature.

SUPERNOTES.name: trial3 describe good
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: How many seconds did it take?
How good was your prediction?
Would this be a good temperature for your bath water?
If not, how could you change the final temperature of the mixture?

SUPERNOTES.name: trial1 describe final
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: What is the final temperature of the combination of water and clay?
How many degrees did the clay change?
How many degrees did the water change?
How did you decide when equilibrium was reached?
How many seconds did it take?

SUPERNOTES.name: trial1 predict design
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Design an insulation to keep the clay at this temperature. You can use any available materials.
Record why you think your design is good in Notes on your handheld computer.

SUPERNOTES.name: trial2 describe monitor
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Monitor the temperature of the clay until it's near to equilibrium. Save your data to the handheld.
How long does it take to reach equilibrium?
Is the time greater or less than you thought it would be?

SUPERNOTES.name: analysis1 describe 1
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: While mixing water at two temperatures, did the result match your prediction?
If they differed, why?
Derive a formula for the final temperature when you mix equal amounts of different temperatures of water.

SUPERNOTES.name: analysis2 describe 2
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Which exchanged heat faster, the water mixed together or the clay in the water?
Why?

SUPERNOTES.name: analysis3 describe 3
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Draw the resulting graph of the clay temperature as it approaches the temperature of the water.
Why do you think it has that shape?

SUPERNOTES.name: analysis4 explain 4
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: Do you think the shape of the clay makes a difference in the results?
Give examples of other shapes besides a ball that you could use and how they would behave differently.

SUPERNOTES.name: analysis5 explain 5
SUPERNOTES.SNPARAGRAPH: How did your method of insulation compare to methods used by others?
Explain why the differences occurred.
